 Episode: Beneath the Surface

It occured to me that the whole situation was Jack's fault.

You're an Air Force Colonel who, along with your team, is on the home turf of people you now know to be completely ruthless and exploitative of their own people. You:

1. Make nice to their leader, get your people home to safety, and then, recommend you don't think diplomatic relations are a good idea because these folks ENSLAVE their own people, or

2. Get on your moral high horse in the Big Bad's office. Start spouting off about how rotten you think they are and how you're just too good to associate with them.

Remember, this is a highly advanced civilization and it's just you and 3 others. You're outnumbered, outarmed, and generally in a position of weakness, not strength.

So naturally Jack picked option 2. This is just another example of the Season 4 lobotomy TPTB gave Jack. IRL he would have been court martialed for egregious stupidity.

Also, the shipper moments were some of the least convincing I've ever seen.

On the positive side, MS looked good in that tunic.

Actually, there could have been a storyline. The team could have been discovered poking around by Calder's men, then captured and 'memory stamped'. Instead we have Jack, alone, unarmed, confronting a man who obviously was capable of very nasty behavior.

Granted, it provided a nice dramatic scene for the actor. But still, I don't believe an experienced, Special Ops Colonel would antagonize someone who was obviously capable of mistreating people, especially, when he was at such a disadvantage.

Btw, you need a Masters degree to make Colonel, and for the last two seasons the writers have made Jack so stupid he wouldn't pass the GED test. It's really getting old.

01-21-2002 10:27 AM
JoJo
Sam/McKay Shipper

Registered: Oct 2001
Location: City by the Great Shellfish Bay
Posts: 394

Venus, I caught the ep in syndication a couple of weeks ago. Jack had a flashback scene where he was in Calder's office telling him that he wouldn't recommend relations and criticised the guy's entire culture. After he finished pissing the guy off, he asked him just how Calder got the slaves to work. Calder's response was "you'll find out". Not too bright of Jack was it? He could have played along, gotten out, and then informed Calder what he thought of him. But of course, that would have assumed Jack's IQ is higher than that of an eggplant's.

My point is, that with a little writing they could have had a fairly plausible ep. Instead, they had Jack acting quite stupidly with the result of putting the team in danger. If it were an isolated incident it wouldn't have irritated me so much, but he's been consistently written as dumb for a long time now. The reason it rubs me the wrong way is because I know the writers can do better, (e.g. The Warrior, where Jack figured out Katano was up to something immediately). I read on another board that TPTB deliberately dumbed Jack down to make him less heroic. Why, I don't know.

Jack is a hothead, always has been. I found it within the limits of plausibility to have him act up in the man's office. And in terms of production costs, it was probably cheaper than doing it the other way (i.e. the team getting caught poking around).

Also, lately it seems they have been making a point of saying Jack only acts dumb. He is aware of more than he lets on.

So what you're saying is, even though Jack consistently behaves as if he were a moron, we should still believe he's smart.

In my experience, when people ACT dumb it's because they really ARE dumb. Intelligent people usually act intelligently.

All I'm saying is that they should get new writers.

Report this post to a moderator | ? + *
01-23-2002 06:53 PM
Sam K
Ice Queen

Registered: Dec 2001
Location: Southeastern USA
Posts: 491

 No...

What I'm saying is that some people deliberately put up a front, to throw others off the scent. I do it myself on occasion, because sometimes I have neither the time nor the patience. I know how smart I am; I see no need to constantly prove it to those around me.

So if that is the situation with Jack, the theory would then be that we are all assuming he's a moron when it is not the case. Presumably we would then get a nice juicy episode wherein Jack proves us all wrong after all this time.

However, I won't hold my breath. I admit it's a stretch.
